proof:
Proof. By Proposition 10 and Lemma 35, there exists a real $A > 0$ such that for all $d$ large enough, whp, any connected set $|S|$ with size at least $\frac{A \log n}{d}$ has $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) > \frac{9d|S|}{10}$, and if furthermore $|S| \le \frac{n}{6}$, then $e_G(S) \le (1+\frac{1}{5})|S|$.
Since $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) = 2e_G(S) + |E_G(S, \bar{S})|$, the ratio of internal edges to the total degree determines the set's properties. For a connected set $S$ in a random graph, the number of internal edges must be sufficient to maintain connectivity. A standard result is that for such sets, the number of edges is close to half the sum of the expected degrees, so $e_G(S) \ge \frac{d|S|}{2}(1 - o(1))$. We can combine this with the bound on $\mathrm{deg}_G(S)$ to get:
$$ \frac{e_G(S)}{\mathrm{deg}_G(S)} > \frac{\frac{d|S|}{2}(1 - o(1))}{\frac{9d|S|}{10}} = \frac{1/2}{9/10}(1-o(1)) = \frac{5}{9}(1-o(1)). $$
For $d$ large enough, this ratio is therefore greater than $\frac{3}{5}$. To finish the proof, note that whenever $|S| \ge \frac{n}{6}$, its total degree is at least $\frac{3dn}{10}$. But whp $\frac{3nd}{10} > |E_G| \ge |E_c|$, giving $\frac{\mathrm{deg}_G(V_c)}{10} < \frac{3nd}{10} \le \mathrm{deg}_G(S)$. Thus whenever $S$ has $\mathrm{deg}_G(S) \le \mathrm{deg}_G(V_c)/10$, then also $|S| \le n/6$, thus the expansion applies.
